[[Rachel Talalay]] | writer = John Waters | starring = {{plainlist| * [[Sonny Bono]] * [[Ruth Brown]] * [[Divine (performer)|Divine]] * [[Debbie Harry]] * [[Ricki Lake]] * [[Jerry Stiller]] * [[Ric Ocasek]] * [[Pia Zadora]]}} | music = [[Kenny Vance]] | cinematography = David Boner | editing = Janice Hampton | studio = [[Stephen Woolley|Palace Pictures]] | distributor = [[New Line Cinema]] | released = {{Film date|1988|2|16|Baltimore|1988|2|26}} | runtime = 92 minutes{{cite web|title=''HAIRSPRAY'' (PG)|url=http://www.bbfc.co.uk/AFF061450/|work=[[British Board of Film Classification]]|date=1988-05-31|accessdate=2012-11-05}} | country = United States | language = English | budget = $2 million | gross = $8.3 million }} '''''Hairspray''''' is a 1988 American [[Dance in film|dance]] [[comedy film]] written and directed by [[John Waters]], and starring [[Ricki Lake]], [[Divine (performer)|Divine]], [[Debbie Harry]], [[Sonny Bono]], [[Jerry Stiller]], Leslie Ann Powers, [[Vitamin C (singer)|Colleen Fitzpatrick]], and [[Michael St. Gerard]]. ''Hairspray'' was a dramatic departure from Waters's earlier works, with a much broader intended audience. ''Hairspray''{{'}}s [[Motion Picture Association of America film rating system|PG]] is the mildest rating a Waters film has received; most of his previous films were rated [[X rating|X]] by the [[Motion Picture Association of America|MPAA]]. Set in 1962 [[Baltimore, Maryland]], the film revolves around self-proclaimed "pleasantly plump" teenager Tracy Turnblad as she pursues stardom as a dancer on a local TV show and rallies against [[racial segregation]]. ''Hairspray'' was only a moderate success upon its initial theatrical release, earning a modest gross of $8 million. However, it managed to attract a larger audience on [[home video]] in the early 1990s and became a [[cult classic]].{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=hairspray.htm|title=Hairspray (1988)|website=[[Box Office Mojo]]|accessdate=2007-06-12}}''Hairspray'' at [http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/1009096-hairspray/ Rotten Tomatoes]; last accessed May 5, 2007. Most critics praised the film, although some were displeased{{Citation needed|date=March 2010}} with the overall [[Camp (style)|campiness]]. The film ranks #444 on [[Empire (film magazine)|''Empire'' magazine]]'s 2008 list of the 500 greatest movies of all time.{{cite web|url=http://www.empireonline.com/500/11.asp |title=Empire Features The 500 Greatest Movies of All Time |website=Empireonline.com |accessdate=August 14, 2011}} In 2002, the film was adapted into a [[Hairspray (musical)|Broadway musical of the same name]], which won eight [[Tony Award]]s, including [[Tony Award for Best Musical|Best Musical]] in 2003. A [[Hairspray (2007 film)|second film version]] of ''Hairspray'', an [[Film adaptation|adaptation]] of the stage musical, was also released by [[New Line Cinema]] in 2007, which included many changes of scripted items from the original. ==Plot== In Baltimore, Maryland in the year 1962, Tracy Turnblad and her best friend, Penny Pingleton, audition for ''The Corny Collins Show'', a popular [[Baltimore]] teenage dance show (based on the real-life ''[[The Buddy Deane Show|Buddy Deane Show]]''). Penny is too nervous and stumbles over her answers, and another girl, Nadine, is cut for being black (the show has a "Negro Day" on the last Thursday of every month, she is told). However, despite being overweight, Tracy is a strong enough dancer to become a regular on the show, infuriating the show's reigning queen, Amber Von Tussle, a mean, privileged, beautiful high school classmate whose racist parents, Velma and Franklin Von Tussle, own Tilted Acres Amusement Park and have banned African Americans from going there. Tracy steals Amber's boyfriend, Link Larkin, and competes against her for the title of Miss Auto Show 1963, fueling Amber's hatred of her. Tracy's growing confidence leads to her being hired as a plus-size model for the Hefty Hideaway clothing store owned by Mr. Pinky. She is also inspired to bleach, tease, and rat her [[big hair]] into styles popular in the 1960s. At school, a teacher brands her hairdo a "hair-don't" and sends her to the principal's office, from which Tracy is sent to [[special education]] classes, where she meets several black classmates who have been put there to hold them back academically. The students introduce Tracy to Motormouth Maybelle, an [[Rhythm and blues|R&B]] record shop owner and host of the monthly "Negro Day" on ''The Corny Collins Show''. They teach Tracy, Penny, and Link dance moves and Penny begins an [[Interracial relationship|interracial romance]] with Motormouth Maybelle's son, Seaweed. This horrifies Penny's parents, Prudence and Paddy, who imprison their daughter in her bedroom and try to [[Brainwashing|brainwash]] her into dating white boys and oppose integration with the help of Dr. Frederickson, a [[quackery|quack]] [[Psychiatry|psychiatrist]]. Seaweed later helps her break out of the house and run away. It is implied that she will never return, as she has finally broken free from her parents. Undeterred, Tracy uses her newfound fame to champion the cause of [[racial integration]] with the help of Motormouth Maybelle, Corny Collins, his assistant Tammy, and her own [[Agoraphobia|agoraphobic]], slightly overbearing, overweight mother, Edna. After a [[race riot]] at Tilted Acres results in Tracy's arrest, the Von Tussles grow more defiant in their opposition to racial integration. They plot to sabotage the Miss Auto Show 1963 pageant with a bomb hidden in Velma's towering bouffant wig. The plan literally blows up in Velma's face when the bomb detonates prematurely, and the Von Tussles are dragged away by the Baltimore police. Tracy, who had won the crown but was disqualified for being in reform school, dethrones Amber after the governor of Maryland pardons her; Tracy then shows up at the pageant, integrates the show, and encourages everyone to dance. ==Cast== * [[Ricki Lake]] as Tracy Turnblad, an optimistic, aspiring teenager who hopes to dance on a TV show as well as promote integration. * [[Divine (performer)|Divine]] as Edna Turnblad, Tracy's kind, plus-sized mother who is ashamed of her obesity. Divine also plays Arvin Hodgepile, the rival TV station owner who is against racial integration for his studio. * [[Debbie Harry]] as Velma Von Tussle, Franklin's wife and Amber's mother. * [[Sonny Bono]] as Franklin Von Tussle, Velma's husband and Amber's father. * [[Jerry Stiller]] as Wilbur Turnblad, Tracy's loving, funny and encouraging father. * [[imdbname:0694572|Leslie Ann Powers]] as Penelope "Penny" Pingleton, Tracy's shy best friend. * [[Vitamin C (singer)|Colleen Fitzpatrick]] as Amber Von Tussle, snobby dancer on The Corny Collins Show. * [[Michael St. Gerard]] as Lincoln "Link" Larkin, a teenage heartthrob, Tracy's boyfriend, and Amber's ex-boyfriend. * [[imdbname:0697628|Clayton Prince]] as Seaweed J. Stubbs, Motormouth Maybelle's son who loves to dance. Seaweed is Penny's main love interest. * [[imdbname:0586933|Cyrkle Milbourne]] as L'il Inez Stubbs, Seaweed's little sister. * [[Ruth Brown]] as Motormouth Maybelle Stubbs, a friendly and strong-willed African American and mother of Seaweed and L'il Inez. * [[Shawn Thompson]] as Corny Collins, the eccentric host of The Corny Collins Show. * [[Mink Stole]] as Tammy, an employee and personal assistant to Corny Collins. * [[Jo Ann Havrilla|Joann Havrilla]] as Prudence Pingleton, Paddy's wife and Penny's overprotective controlling mother who doesn't approve of Penny dating Seaweed. * [[imdbname:0731042|Doug Roberts]] as Patrick "Paddy" Pingleton, Prudence's husband and Penny's no nonsense father who wants to protect Penny from Seaweed. * [[imdbname:0920863|Alan J. Wendl]] as Mr. Pinky, the owner of the Hefty Hideaway clothing store. * [[Toussaint McCall]] as himself (Though appearing as a man in his 50s, rather than in his 20s, as he would have been in 1962) * [[John Waters]] as Dr. Fredrickson, a psychiatrist who helps Prudence and Paddy try to brainwash Penny into only dating white boys. ;Council members * [[Josh Charles]] as Iggy * [[Jason Downs]] as Bobby * [[Holter Graham]] as I.Q. * Dan Griffith as Brad * Regina Hammond as Pam * Bridget Kimsey as Consuella * Frankie Maldon as Dash * Brooke Stacy Mills as Lou Ann * John Orofino as Fender * Kim Webb as Carmelita * Debra Wirth as Shelly ;Special appearances * [[Ric Ocasek]] as the [[Beatnik]] cat * [[Pia Zadora]] as the Beatnik chick ==Production== [[John Waters]] wrote the screenplay under the title of ''White Lipstick'', with the story loosely based on real events. The ''Corny Collins Show'' is based on the real-life ''[[The Buddy Deane Show|Buddy Deane Show]]'', a local dance party program which pre-empted Dick Clark's ''[[American Bandstand]]'' in the Baltimore area during the 1950s and early 1960s.{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Hairspray-Sonny-Bono/dp/B00006RZ9Y|title='Hairspray' DVD Commentary by: John Waters and Ricki Lake|author=[[John Waters]]; [[Ricki Lake]]|date=November 5, 2002|work=[[New Line Cinema|New Line Home Video]]}} Waters had previously written about ''The Buddy Deane Show'' in his 1983 book ''Crackpot: The Obsessions of John Waters.'' [[Principal photography]] took place in and around the Baltimore area during the summer of 1987.{{cite book|author=[[Robert Maier]]|date=2011|title=Low Budget Hell: Making Underground Movies with John Waters|url=|location=Davidson, North Carolina, U.S.A.|publisher=Full Page Publishing|pages=273–297|isbn=978-0-9837708-0-0}} The school scenes were filmed at [[Perry Hall High School]] with set locations including the library, a first-floor English class, and the principal's office.{{cite web|url=http://www.bcpl.info/info/history/hist_pe_schools.html |title=Perry Hall's Schools: The Heart of the Community |author=David Marks |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090101004408/http://www.bcpl.info/info/history/hist_pe_schools.html |archivedate=January 1, 2009 }} In the scene set in the principal's office, the Harry Dorsey Gough (see [[Perry Hall Mansion]]) coat-of-arms that once hung in the main lobby can be seen through the doorway.{{cite web|url=http://www.perryhallmaryland.org/funfacts|title=Fun Facts About Perry Hall|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090709085526/http://www.perryhallmaryland.org/funfacts|archivedate=2009-07-09|df=}} The scenes set at Tilted Acres amusement park were filmed at [[Dorney Park]] in [[Allentown, Pennsylvania]]. The film was [[Divine (performer)|Divine]]'s final film; he died three weeks after the film's release. ''Hairspray'' was his only film with Waters in which he didn't play the lead. Originally, Divine was considered to play both Tracy Turnblad and her mother Edna. Executives from New Line Cinema, the film's distributor, discouraged this concept, and it was eventually dropped.{{cite book|last1=Egan|first1=James|title=John Waters: Interviews|publisher=University Press of Mississippi|isbn=9781617031823|pages=xxiii|edition=Paperback}} Instead Divine played Edna Turnblad and Arvin Hodgepile, racist TV station owner. ===Deleted scenes=== A handful of [[Deleted scene|scenes were cut]] while in post-production, some of which explained certain elements seen in the film. The first scene occurs before Tracy and Penny go the Parkville VFW record hop. Tracy is required to start her first shift working in the Hardy-Har Joke Shop. But after managing to scare away all her customers she is excused to go to the hop. The joke shop customers are still listed in the end credits of the final cut. Another involves Tracy skipping school, stealing shoes from the Etta Gown Shop, and breaking into the Von Tussles' home, using Amber's hair bleach to bleach her hair in Amber's sink, thus explaining Tracy's change of hair color later in the film. Another deleted scene involved live roaches crawling out of Tracy's hair at Tilted Acres. The actual filmed scene of the cockroach crawling out of Tracy's hair is cut, but still included is Amber's horrified reaction. However, she is presumed to be joking and/or lying. When discussing his decision to ultimately cut the scene, Waters explained "[[Robert Shaye|Bob Shaye]], the head of New Line, probably correctly, said, 'This doesn't work. What is this, a [[Luis Buñuel|Buñuel]] movie?' [...] And he was probably right." A further excised scene sees Penny and Seaweed trying to take refuge at Nadine's home after Penny's escape. The final deleted scene was a musical number which involved the teens performing an obscure 1960s dance called "The Stupidity" at the auto show just prior to Tracy being released from reform school, but again, Waters ultimately decided it wasn't appropriate, stating, "[B]asically, I thought, you know, you don't want your leading man to look stupid right in the big finale." ==Reception== ===Critical reception=== ''Hairspray'' received three stars from critics [[Gene Siskel]] and [[Roger Ebert]].{{cite news| url=https://www.rogerebert.com/reviews/hairspray-1988 | work=RogerEbert.com | title=Hairspray |last=Ebert |first=Roger |publisher=Ebert Digital LLC |date=February 26, 1988 |accessdate= April 10, 2018}} The film currently holds a 98% "fresh" rating on [[Rotten Tomatoes]], based on 41 reviews with an average rating of 7.8/10. It is Waters' second-highest-rated film (behind ''[[Multiple Maniacs]]'') on the website. The critical consensus states that "''Hairspray'' is perhaps John Waters' most accessible film, and as such, it's a gently subversive slice of retro hilarity."{{rotten-tomatoes|1009096-hairspray|Hairspray}} John Waters wrote that his all-time favorite review of ''Hairspray'' was [[David Edelstein]]'s in ''[[Rolling Stone]]'': "A family movie both the Bradys and the Mansons could adore".{{cite book|author=Waters, John|title=Crackpot: The Obsessions of John Waters|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tr7lYLTXmFYC|accessdate=27 September 2017|date=1 November 2007|publisher=Simon and Schuster|isbn=978-1-4165-9124-5|chapter=Finally, Footlights on the Fat Girls}} ===Box office=== ''Hairspray'' opened on February 26, 1988 in 79 North American theaters, where it grossed {{USD}}577,287 in its opening weekend. On March 11, it [[Wide release|expanded]] to 227 theaters, where it grossed $966,672 from March 11–13. It ended its theatrical run with $8,271,108.{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?page=weekend&id=hairspray.htm |title=Hairspray (1988) |website=Box Office Mojo |accessdate=August 14, 2011}} ===Awards=== The film was nominated for six [[Independent Spirit Award]]s, and the Grand Jury Prize at the [[Sundance Film Festival]].{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0095270/awards|work=IMDB|title= Awards for Hairspray}} ==Other works== ===Broadway musical=== {{Main|Hairspray (musical)}} In mid-2002, [[Margo Lion]] teamed with writers [[Marc Shaiman]] and [[Thomas Meehan (writer)|Thomas Meehan]] to turn ''Hairspray'' into a [[Broadway musical]] production. The show opened on August 15, 2002 starring [[Marissa Jaret Winokur]] as Tracy and [[Harvey Fierstein]] as Edna. The show went on to win eight [[Tony Awards]], including [[Tony Award for Best Musical|Best Musical]], in 2003. The show closed on January 4, 2009. ===2007 film adaptation=== {{Main|Hairspray (2007 film)}} In 2006, New Line Cinema joined forces with [[Adam Shankman]] to adapt the Broadway show into a movie musical. The film was released July 20, 2007, starring [[John Travolta]] as Edna, [[Michelle Pfeiffer]] as Velma, [[Christopher Walken]] as Wilbur, [[Amanda Bynes]] as Penny Pingleton, [[Brittany Snow]] as Amber Von Tussle, [[Queen Latifah]] as Motormouth Maybelle, [[James Marsden]] as Corny, [[Zac Efron]] as Link, and newcomer [[Nikki Blonsky]] as Tracy. The film had a $75 million budget and earned over $200 million worldwide.{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=hairspray07.htm |title=Hairspray (2007) |website=BoxOfficeMojo.com |accessdate=August 14, 2011}} ===2016 live television adaptation=== {{Main|Hairspray Live!}} [[NBC]] aired a special television event of the acclaimed musical on December 7, 2016, starring [[Harvey Fierstein]] as Edna, [[Ariana Grande]] as Penny Pingleton, [[Kristin Chenoweth]] as Velma, [[Martin Short]] as Wilbur, [[Dove Cameron]] as Amber Von Tussle, [[Jennifer Hudson]] as Motormouth Maybelle, [[Derek Hough]] as Corny, [[Garrett Clayton]] as Link, and newcomer Maddie Baillio as Tracy. It was well received by critics and was seen by 9.05 million viewers, with a ratings share of 2.3 in the 18–49 demographic, and a 5.9 overnight household rating. ==Soundtrack== {{Main|Hairspray (1988 soundtrack)}} The soundtrack was released in 1988 by [[MCA Records]]. The album featured one original song by [[Rachel Sweet]] and eleven other songs mostly from the early 1960s by [[Gene Pitney]], [[Toussaint McCall]] and [[The Ikettes]], among others. Two songs, "[[You Don't Own Me]]" and "Mama Didn't Lie", came out in 1964 and 1963 respectively. ;Additional songs Other songs appear in the film, but are not on the soundtrack, due to licensing restrictions, because many of the songs listed were on [[Cameo Parkway Records]], a recording label owned by Allen Klein.{{clarify|date=January 2016}} * "[[Limbo Rock]]" – [[Chubby Checker]] * "[[Let's Twist Again]]" - Chubby Checker * "[[The Banana Boat Song|Day-O]]" – [[Pia Zadora]] * "[[Duke of Earl]]" – [[Gene Chandler]] * "Train to Nowhere" – [[The Champs]] * "Dancin' Party" – Chubby Checker * "The Fly" – Chubby Checker * "The Bird" – The Dutones (not to be confused with [[The Five Du-Tones]], who are also featured on the soundtrack) * "[[Pony Time]]" – Chubby Checker * "Hide and Go Seek" – [[Bunker Hill (musician)|Bunker Hill]] * "[[Mashed Potato Time]]" – [[Dee Dee Sharp]] * "Gravy (For My Mashed Potatoes)" – Dee Dee Sharp * "Waddle, Waddle" – The Bracelets * "Do the New Continental" – [[The Dovells]] * "[[You Don't Own Me]]" – [[Lesley Gore]] * "Life's Too Short" – The Lafayettes ==Home media== ''Hairspray'' was issued for the first time on [[VHS]] and [[LaserDisc]] in 1989 by [[Sony Pictures Home Entertainment|RCA/Columbia Pictures Home Video]]. [[New Line Cinema|New Line]] reissued the film on VHS in 1996. The film was released on [[DVD]] by New Line in 2002. The disc included an [[audio commentary]] by John Waters and Ricki Lake and a [[Trailer (promotion)|theatrical trailer]]. It was released on [[Blu-ray Disc|Blu-ray]] on March 4, 2014.{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Hairspray-Blu-ray-Divine/dp/B00GGT4OK6/ref=sr_1_10?ie=UTF8&qid=1393101203&sr=8-10&keywords=hairspray|title=Hairspray|author=|date=4 March 2014|publisher=|accessdate=21 March 2018|via=Amazon}} ==See also== {{Portalbar|1980s|Television in the United States|Comedy}} * [[Cross-dressing in film and television]] * [[Racial integration]] * [[African-American Civil Rights Movement in popular culture]] * [[Multiculturalism]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|0095270}} * {{mojo title|hairspray}} * {{rotten-tomatoes|1009096-hairspray}} * {{metacritic film|hairspray-1988}} {{John Waters}} {{Hairspray}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hairspray}} [[Category:1988 films]] [[Category:1980s romantic comedy films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American romantic comedy films]] [[Category:American satirical films]] [[Category:American teen comedy films]] [[Category:American teen romance films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films directed by John Waters]] [[Category:African-American civil rights movement (1954–68) in film]] [[Category:Culture of Baltimore]] [[Category:Films adapted into plays]] [[Category:Films about race and ethnicity]] [[Category:Films about television]] [[Category:Films set in Baltimore]] [[Category:Films set in 1962]] [[Category:Films shot in Baltimore]] [[Category:Films shot in Maryland]] [[Category:American independent films]] [[Category:Films about interracial romance]]

{{about|the [[Michael Jackson]] song|the concept in Jewish moral philosophy|Tikkun olam}} {{Infobox song | name = Heal the World | cover = Michael Jackson - Heal the World.png | alt = | border = yes | type = single | artist = [[Michael Jackson]] | album = [[Dangerous (Michael Jackson album)|Dangerous]] | B-side = She Drives Me Wild | released = 1992 | format = {{hlist|[[CD single|CD]]|[[cassette single|cassette]]|[[7"]]|[[12-inch single|12"]]}} | recorded = 1989{{cite web|first= Mike |last= Smallcombe |title= The making of Michael Jackson's Dangerous PART ONE |date= November 27, 2016 |accessdate= June 18, 2017 |url= https://www.makingmichael.co.uk/single-post/2016/11/27/The-making-of-Michael-Jacksons-Dangerous-PART-ONE}} | studio = | venue = | genre = | length = {{unbulleted list|6:25 (album version)|4:32 (7" edit)|4:55 (7" edit with intro)}} | label = [[Epic Records|Epic]] | writer = [[Michael Jackson]] | producer = {{hlist|Michael Jackson|[[Bruce Swedien]] (co-producer)}} | prev_title = [[Who Is It (Michael Jackson song)|Who Is It]] | prev_year = 1992 | next_title = [[Give In to Me]] | next_year = 1993 | misc = {{Audio sample | type = single | file = Michael Jackson - Heal the World.ogg }} {{External music video|{{YouTube|BWf-eARnf6U|"Heal The World"}} }} }} "'''Heal the World'''" is a song recorded by American recording artist [[Michael Jackson]] from his eighth studio album, ''[[Dangerous (Michael Jackson album)|Dangerous]]'' (1991). It was released in 1992 as the fifth single from the album. It was written and composed by Jackson, and produced by Jackson and [[Bruce Swedien]]. In a 2001 [[Online chat|Internet chat]] with [[Fan (person)|fans]], Jackson said that "Heal the World" is the song he was most proud to have created. He also created the ''[[Heal the World Foundation]]'', a charitable organization which was designed to improve the lives of children. The organization was also meant to teach children how to help others. This concept of 'betterment for all' would become a centerpiece for the [[Dangerous World Tour]]. In the documentary ''[[Living with Michael Jackson]]'', Jackson said he created the song in his "Giving Tree" at [[Neverland Ranch]]. An ensemble performance of "[[We Are the World]]" and "Heal the World" closed [[Michael Jackson memorial service|Jackson's memorial service]] at the Staples Center in Los Angeles on July 7, 2009. The song was performed as rehearsed by Jackson at the venue just weeks earlier, in preparation for his planned "[[This Is It (concerts)|This Is It]]" concerts in London along with "[[Dirty Diana]]". R&B singer [[Ciara]] sang the song as a tribute to Jackson at the [[BET Awards|2009 BET Awards]]. The song was played at the funeral of [[Murder of James Bulger|James Bulger]],Miles, Tina (October 8, 2009). {{cite web|url= http://www.liverpooldailypost.co.uk/liverpool-news/regional-news/2009/10/08/michael-jackson-s-heal-the-world-released-to-support-new-liverpool-james-bulger-centre-for-bullied-children-92534-24879959/ |title= Michael Jackson's Heal The World released to support new Liverpool James Bulger centre for bullied children |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091016040814/http://www.liverpooldailypost.co.uk/liverpool-news/regional-news/2009/10/08/michael-jackson-s-heal-the-world-released-to-support-new-liverpool-james-bulger-centre-for-bullied-children-92534-24879959/ |archivedate= October 16, 2009}}. ''[[Liverpool Daily Post]]''. and Jackson also donated the song to be used as the anthem for the charity the James Bulger Red Balloon Centre, a school for children to go to if they are being bullied or have learning difficulties.Hamilton, Julian (June 6, 2009). {{cite web|url= http://www.clickliverpool.com/news/local-news/124665-heal-the-world-song-launched-for-red-balloon-centre-in-liverpool.html |title='Heal The World' song launched for Red Balloon Centre in Liverpool |archiveurl= https://archive.is/20120222112541/http://www.clickliverpool.com/news/local-news/124665-heal-the-world-song-launched-for-red-balloon-centre-in-liverpool.html |archivedate= February 22, 2012}}. ''Click Liverpool''. ==Composition== This song is written in the key of [[A major]], and it spans from E4 to C#6. It has a tempo of 80 beats per minute.{{cite web|title= Heal the World By Michael Jackson – Digital Sheet Music |url= http://www.musicnotes.com/sheetmusic/mtdFPE.asp?ppn=MN0041797 |publisher= MusicNotes.com. [[Sony/ATV Music Publishing]] |accessdate= September 27, 2012}} ==Reception== The song reached number two in the [[UK Singles Chart]] in December 1992, kept off the number one position by [[Whitney Houston]]'s "[[I Will Always Love You]]". It peaked number 27 on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]]. [[AllMusic]] editor [[Stephen Thomas Erlewine]] called this song "middle-class soft."{{cite web|first= Stephen Thomas |last= Erlewine |authorlink= Stephen Thomas Erlewine |title= Michael Jackson – Dangerous |publisher= [[AllMusic]]. [[All Media Network]] |url= http://www.allmusic.com/album/dangerous-mw0000674875 |accessdate= February 15, 2014}} David Browne of ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' praised the song: "And when his voice isn't competing with drum machines, it has rarely sounded stronger-achingly pure on ''Heal the World,''"{{cite magazine|first= David |last= Browne |title= MUSIC REVIEW – Dangerous (1991) – Michael Jackson |url= http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,316329,00.html |magazine= [[Entertainment Weekly]] |date= November 29, 1991 |accessdate= February 15, 2014}} ''Rolling Stone''{{'}}s Alan Light was not satisfied, calling it "a Hallmark-card knockoff of "We Are the World."{{cite web|first= Alan |last= Light |title= Michael Jackson – Dangerous |magazine= [[Rolling Stone]] |url= https://www.rollingstone.com/music/albumreviews/dangerous-19920101 |date= January 1, 1992 |accessdate= February 15, 2014}} ==Music video== The music video (directed by [[Joe Pytka]]) features children living in countries suffering from [[unrest]], especially [[Burundi]]. It is also one of only a handful of Michael Jackson's videos not to feature Jackson himself, the others being "[[Cry (Michael Jackson song)|Cry]]", "[[HIStory/Ghosts|HIStory]]" and "[[Man in the Mirror]]". (The clips for "[[HIStory/Ghosts|HIStory]]" and "[[Man in the Mirror]]" only feature Michael Jackson in archival footage).{{cite video|url= https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yTMjA4ZJUqo#t=2m50s |title= Heal the World (Music Video) |publisher= [[Epic Records]]. [[YouTube]] |accessdate= July 6, 2009}} The version of the video included on ''[[Dangerous: The Short Films]]'' and ''[[Michael Jackson's Vision]]'' contains an introductory video that features a speech from Jackson taken from the special "spoken word" version of the track. This version was not included on ''[[Video Greatest Hits – HIStory]]'' featuring the music video. {{Infobox film | name = I Spit on Your Grave | image = I Spit on your Grave.jpg | alt = | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Steven R. Monroe]] | producer = [[Lisa M. Hansen]]
[[Paul Hertzberg]] | screenplay = Stuart Morse | based on = {{based on|''I''ll spit on your graves"|[[Boris Vian]]}} | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[Sarah Butler]] * [[Jeff Branson]] * [[Daniel Franzese]] * [[Rodney Eastman]] * [[Chad Lindberg]] * [[Tracey Walter]] * [[Andrew Howard]] }} | music = Corey Allen Jackson | cinematography = Neil Lisk | editing = Daniel Duncan | studio = [[CineTel Films]] | distributor = [[Anchor Bay Entertainment]] | released = {{Film date|2010|5|1|[[Texas Frightmare Weekend]]|2010|10|8|United States|ref2={{cite web|url=http://www.bloody-disgusting.com/news/18222|title=First Word on 'I Spit on Your Grave' Remake}}{{cite web|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/films.php?id=63440|title=I Spit On Your Grave|publisher=[[CraveOnline]]|work=ComingSoon.net|accessdate=August 20, 2010}}}} | runtime = 108 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = $2 million{{mojo title|ispitonyourgrave|I Spit on Your Grave}} | gross = $572,809 }} '''''I Spit on Your Grave''''' is a 2010 American [[Rape and revenge films|rape-and-revenge]] [[horror film]] and a [[remake]] of the controversial 1978 [[cult film]] ''[[I Spit on Your Grave|of the same name]]'' (originally known as ''Day of the Woman'').{{cite web|url=http://www.bloody-disgusting.com/news/19164|title=Anchor Bay's 'I Spit on Your Grave' Remake Gets Theatrical Run}} It was directed by Steven R. Monroe,{{cite web |url=http://www.bloody-disgusting.com/news/12483 |title=BD Horror News – '78 Classic 'I Spit on Your Grave' Gets Remade |publisher=Bloody-disgusting.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100525155754/http://www.bloody-disgusting.com/news/12483 |archivedate=2010-05-25 |df= }} and stars [[Sarah Butler]], [[Chad Lindberg]], [[Daniel Franzese]], [[Rodney Eastman]], [[Jeff Branson]], and [[Andrew Howard]].{{cite web|url=http://www.bloody-disgusting.com/news/18205|title=Full Cast Revealed for Anchor Bay's 'I Spit on Your Grave' Remake}} ==Plot== Novelist Jennifer Hills travels from New York City to Louisiana to work on her next book in privacy. When she becomes lost while searching for the cabin she has rented, she stops for gas and to ask for directions. The attendant Johnny gives her directions and tries to flirt with her, to no avail. Around the cabin, Jennifer spends the following days writing, tanning, hiking, smoking marijuana and drinking alcohol. When the cabin's plumbing becomes clogged, it is fixed by Matthew, a stuttering plumber who has social interaction disability. She rewards him with an abrupt kiss of gratitude. Matthew then tells Johnny and his friends Andy and Stanley about his visit. Johnny, whose ego was bruised after the gas station incident, decide that Jennifer is snobbish and needs to be "taught a lesson". That night, the four men sneak into Jennifer's cabin and assault her, although Matthew refuses to participate. She escapes into the woods and bumps into Sheriff Storch and Earl, the owner of the cabin she is renting. Storch takes Jennifer back to the cabin, but when he finds her drugs and alcohol, he assaults her too. When Johnny, Matthew, Andy, and Stanley return, all of the men take turns raping her — including the reluctant Matthew. Stanley records everything with his video camera. Afterward, just as Storch is about to shoot her, Jennifer falls in the water and escapes. When they fail to find her, Storch tells the others to destroy any evidence of their crimes, including Stanley's videotape. Jennifer begins to stalk her rapists to learn details of their lives. Stanley tells Andy and Johnny that his camera has been stolen — along with the tape of their assault on Jennifer, which had never been destroyed. Later that night, Johnny hears noises outside his house and finds evidence that suggests Matthew had been hiding in the yard. Storch intercepts a tape sent to his wife and confronts Stanley, Andy, and Johnny to find out who sent it. Johnny and Andy suspect Matthew, but they don't know where he is. Afterward, when they go hunting, Storch kills Earl with his shotgun, saying that he is taking care of "loose ends". Matthew returns to the cabin, where he finds Jennifer. He attempts to apologize to her, but she tells him it's not enough and strangles him. She next captures Stanley in a bear trap, smears fish guts in his face, then uses his camera to record crows pecking out his eyes. Jennifer then drowns Andy and burns his face horribly in a lye bathtub. Next, she uses pliers to pull out Johnny's teeth and a pair of garden shears to cut off his penis, leaving him to bleed to death. After killing Johnny, Jennifer visits Storch's family, posing as their daughter's new teacher. She takes the daughter to the park and, when Storch tracks her there, Jennifer knocks him unconscious. When he wakes up, Jennifer anally rapes him with his shotgun and reminds him that she was just as innocent as his own daughter. She attaches one end of a string to the trigger and the other end to the wrist of the unconscious Matthew, who is seated in front of Storch. When Matthew wakes up, his movements trigger the shotgun, which fires a round that tears through Storch's body and blows apart his face before hitting Matthew in the chest, leaving both men dead. Sitting outside, Jennifer hears the gunshot and smiles coldly. ==Cast== * [[Sarah Butler]]{{cite web|url=http://www.bloody-disgusting.com/news/20842|title=FanTasia '10: Say What? A Third 'I Spit On Your Grave' Image?!}} as [[Jennifer Hills]] * [[Rodney Eastman]]{{cite web|url=http://www.bloody-disgusting.com/news/20049|title=Early Look at Trailer for New 'I Spit on Your Grave'}}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} as Andy * [[Daniel Franzese]]{{cite web|url=http://www.dreadcentral.com/news/37288/first-look-teaser-trailer-i-spit-your-grave-redux|title=First Look at Teaser Trailer: I Spit on Your Grave Redux}} as Stanley * [[Jeff Branson]]{{cite web|url=http://www.dreadcentral.com/news/37304/official-i-spit-your-grave-one-sheet|title=Official I Spit on Your Grave One-Sheet}} as John "Johnny" Miller * [[Andrew Howard]] as Sheriff Storch * [[Chad Lindberg]] as Matthew, the plumber with social disorders * [[Tracey Walter]]{{cite web|url=http://www.dreadcentral.com/news/38450/sexy-new-one-sheet-i-spit-your-grave-redux|title=Sexy New One-Sheet – I Spit on Your Grave Redux}} as Earl * [[Mollie Milligan]]{{cite web|url=http://www.bloody-disgusting.com/news/20061|title=Hi-Res Unwatermarked One Sheet for 'I Spit On Your Grave' Remake!}} as Mrs. Storch, the sheriff's wife * [[Saxon Sharbino]]{{cite web|url=http://www.dreadcentral.com/news/37665/weekend-horrors-more-details-i-spit-your-grave|title=Weekend of Horrors: More Details: I Spit on Your Grave}} as Chastity Storch, the sheriff's daughter * Amber Dawn Landrum{{cite web|url=http://www.dreadcentral.com/news/38014/exclusive-director-steven-r-monroe-spills-monroe-spills-i-spit-on-your-grave-receive-unra|title=Exclusive: Director Steven R. Monroe Spills – I Spit On Your Grave to Receive Unrated Theatrical Release!}} as Girl at Gas Station ==Production== [[Principal photography]] began on November 2, 2009, under Steven R. Monroe's direction.{{cite web |url=http://www.brutalashell.com/2009/11/i-spit-on-your-grave-remake-begins-production/ |title=I Spit on Your Grave Remake Begins Production |publisher=Brutal As Hell |date=2009-11-02 |accessdate=2011-02-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091106043138/http://www.brutalashell.com/2009/11/i-spit-on-your-grave-remake-begins-production/ |archivedate=2009-11-06 |df= }} It was distributed by CineTel, and produced by the company's president and CEO [[Paul Hertzberg]].{{cite web|url=http://www.bloody-disgusting.com/news/19858|title=An Itty Bitty Look at the 'I Spit on Your Grave' Promo Art}} Lisa Hansen, Jeff Klein, Alan Ostroff, Gary Needle, and [[Meir Zarchi]] (director of the original) served as [[executive producer]]s.{{cite web|url=http://defamer.gawker.com/394963/i-spit-on-your-grave-remake-promises-even-motorboatier-disembowlements-than-before |title='I Spit on Your Grave' Remake Promises Even Motorboatier |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100325122045/http://defamer.gawker.com/394963/i-spit-on-your-grave-remake-promises-even-motorboatier-disembowlements-than-before |archivedate=2010-03-25 |df= }} Location filming took place in [[Louisiana]].{{cite web|url=http://www.dreadcentral.com/news/34708/cast-taking-shape-anchor-bays-i-spit-your-grave-reduxan|title=Cast Takes Shape for Anchor Bay's I Spit on Your Grave Redux}} The film was written by Stuart Morse, based on Zarchi's screenplay. ==Release== [[CineTel Films]] planned a 2010 worldwide theatrical release.{{cite web|last=Brunton |first=Richard |url=http://www.filmstalker.co.uk/archives/2009/09/i_spit_on_your_grave_remake_go.html |title=I Spit on Your Grave remake going hard |publisher=Filmstalker |date=2009-09-05 |accessdate=2011-02-13}} The film was part of the [[Texas Frightmare Weekend]] on May 1, 2010 in the Sheraton Grand Hotel in [[Irving, Texas]],{{cite web|url=http://www.dreadcentral.com/news/37203/anchor-bay-bring-horror-texas-frightmare-weekend|title=Anchor Bay to Bring the Horror to the Texas Frightmare Weekend}} and part of the Film4 Frightfest on August 29, 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.dreadcentral.com/news/38344/film4-frightfest-10-new-still-i-spit-your-grave|title=Film4 Frightfest '10 – New Still: I Spit on Your Grave}} The Canadian unrated version premiered{{cite web|url=http://www.bloody-disgusting.com/news/20880|title=FanTasia '10 Review: Slatter Fun in 'I Spit on Your Grave'}} at the [[Fantasia Festival]] on July 20, 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.bloody-disgusting.com/news/20800|title=FanTasia '10: Another New Image from 'I Spit On Your Grave'}} The complete cast and [[Meir Zarchi]], director of the [[I Spit on Your Grave|original]], were present.{{cite web|url=http://www.dreadcentral.com/news/38476/fantasia-2010-day-4|title=Fantasia 2010: Day 4}} An unrated version was followed in [[limited release]] on October 8, 2010, in the United States. Coincidentally, another unrated horror film, ''[[Hatchet II]]'', opened a week beforehand.{{cite web|url=http://www.bloody-disgusting.com/news/20855|title=Sex and Violence Sold in Sexy 'I Spit On Your Grave' One Sheet Debut!}} ===Home media=== The film is distributed in the [[United States]], [[Canada]], [[Australia]] and the [[United Kingdom|UK]] by [[Anchor Bay Entertainment]].{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/hr/content_display/news/e3iccd499946ba0cc760d433f239992d5cc|title=Anchor Bay to release 'Grave' remake | work=The Hollywood Reporter | first=Gregg|last=Kilday|date=2010-10-13}} The DVD and [[Blu-ray Disc|Blu-ray]] were released in the United States on February 8, 2011. The DVD includes an [[audio commentary]] by director Steven R. Monroe and producer [[Lisa M. Hansen|Lisa Hansen]], 11 [[deleted scene]]s and [[Trailer (film)|teasers and trailers]]. The DVD was banned in [[New Zealand]], just before its April release.{{cite web|url=http://www.onfilm.co.nz/?p=5223|title=Censor spits on Grave|work=OnFilm|accessdate=6 May 2011}} ==Critical reception== Critical reaction to the film has been generally negative, with a 33% rating on [[Rotten Tomatoes]].{{rotten-tomatoes|i_spit_on_your_grave_2010|I Spit on Your Grave}} On [[Metacritic]] the film was assigned a rating of 27% based on reviews from 14 critics, indicating "generally unfavorable reviews".http://www.metacritic.com/movie/i-spit-on-your-grave [[Roger Ebert]] gave the film a zero-star rating (the same one he'd given the original) and described it as the "despicable remake of the despicable 1978 film". He claimed that it added "a phony sense of moral equivalency", stating "If I rape you, I have committed a crime. If you kill me, you have committed another one. The ideal outcome would be two people unharmed in the first place." While he allowed that the movie was made "professionally," as opposed to the original version that was devoid of any kind of skills or artistry, he considered this largely in the service of the truly offensive material, the rape scenes, later summarizing "this [version] is more offensive, because it lingers lovingly and at greater length on realistic verbal, psychological and physical violence against the woman, and then reduces her 'revenge' to cartoonish horror-flick impossibilities."{{cite news|url=http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20101006/REVIEWS/101009983 |title=I Spit on Your Grave :: rogerebert.com :: Reviews |publisher=Rogerebert.suntimes.com |date= 2010-10-06|accessdate=2011-02-13}}{{cite news |author=the Your Movie Sucks™ files |url=http://blogs.suntimes.com/ebert/your-movie-sucks.html |title=the Your Movie Sucks™ files - Roger Ebert's Journal |publisher=Blogs.suntimes.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110624124437/http://blogs.suntimes.com/ebert/your-movie-sucks.html |archivedate=2011-06-24 |df= }} [[Mick LaSalle]] of the ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'' wrote, "In addition to all the obvious things that are disgusting about this movie, ''I Spit on Your Grave'' is trying to get us to hate each other. Hate it instead. It makes more sense and the hatred is much more deserved."{{cite news|author=Mick LaSalle, Chronicle Movie Critic |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2010/10/07/MV4E1FP5P6.DTL |title=Review: 'I Spit on Your Grave' |publisher=Sfgate.com |date=2010-10-08 |accessdate=2011-02-13}} Critic Andrew O'Hehir also denounced the notion that the film has a message, writing that it "just piles imaginary atrocities on top of real ones, and then halfheartedly claims that it means something. Well, it doesn't."{{cite web|url=http://www.salon.com/2010/10/07/spit_on_grave/story=/ent/movies/andrew_ohehir/2010/10/07/spit_on_grave|title="I Spit on Your Grave": Bogus feminist torture porn lives!|author=Andrew O'Hehir}} Some support for the film in mainstream press came from ''[[The New York Times]]'', which wrote, "Female-empowerment fantasy or just plain prurience, 'Grave' is extremely efficient [[grindhouse]]."{{cite news|last=Catsoulis |first=Jeannette |url=https://movies.nytimes.com/2010/10/08/movies/08spit.html?ref=movies |title=Movie Review - 'I Spit on Your Grave' - An Exploitation Film, Remade - NYTimes.com |publisher=Movies.nytimes.com |date=2010-10-07 |accessdate=2011-02-13}} V.A. Musetto, from the ''[[New York Post]]'', also offered some support for the film, stating, "If you can handle it, see it."{{cite news |url=http://www.nypost.com/p/entertainment/movies/grave_expectations_in_redneck_country_zOdjIyUNQfOdOLyttnhpOI |title='I Spit on Your Grave' movie review |publisher=NYPOST.com |date=2010-10-08 |accessdate=2011-02-13 |first=V.A. |last=Musetto |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101013103942/http://www.nypost.com/p/entertainment/movies/grave_expectations_in_redneck_country_zOdjIyUNQfOdOLyttnhpOI# |archive-date=2010-10-13 |dead-url=yes |df= }} Like the original, the film did find limited cult support. ''[[Fangoria]]'' magazine wrote that ''I Spit on Your Grave'' "...is just as raw and upsetting in its onscreen brutality as the original. Perhaps more so, since the acting is significantly better this time around".{{cite web|author= Oct 08, 2010 |url=http://fangoria.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=2271:i-spit-on-your-grave-film-review&catid=50:movies-tv&Itemid=181 |title="I SPIT ON YOUR GRAVE" (Film Review) |publisher=Fangoria.com |date=2010-10-08 |accessdate=2011-02-13}} ==Sequels== A sequel, ''[[I Spit on Your Grave 2]]'', directed by Steven R. Monroe, was produced and was given a limited theatrical release on September 20, 2013. The film's plot concerns a young aspiring model named Katie (Jemma Dallender) who accepts an offer to have photos taken for her modeling portfolio. Unfortunately for Katie, little does she know the event turns into a nightmare of torture, rape and kidnapping. The story has a rape-revenge plot similar to the first film. In March 2015 [[Anchor Bay Entertainment]] announced ''[[I Spit on Your Grave III: Vengeance Is Mine]]'', the third installment of the [[I Spit on Your Grave|franchise]].[http://bloody-disgusting.com/exclusives/3337017/anchor-bay-acquires-spit-grave-vengeance-mine-exclusive/ Anchor Bay Acquires ‘I Spit On Your Grave: Vengeance is Mine’! ] [[Sarah Butler]] returned to her role as Jennifer Hills and R.D. Braunstein as the director of the film.[http://angstrated.com/2014/04/i-spit-on-your-grave-3-erste-infos/ I SPIT ON YOUR GRAVE 3 | Erste Infos - AngstRated.com] ==References== {{Reflist|2|refs= {{cite web|url=http://www.dreadcentral.com/news/34738/exclusive-rodney-eastman-talks-i-spit-on-your-grave-plus-image|title=Exclusive: Rodney Eastman Talks I Spit On Your Grave Plus Image!|author=SeanD|date=2010-11-30|publisher=Dread Central Media|accessdate=2011-11-07}} }} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.ispitonyourgravemovie.com}}(US) * {{Official website|http://www.ispitonyourgravemovie.co.uk}}{{Dead link|date=January 2015}} (UK) * {{Official website|http://onamstit.ru/}} (Russia) * {{IMDb title|1242432|I Spit on Your Grave}} * {{Allmovie title|516730|I Spit on Your Grave}} * {{mojo title|ispitonyourgrave|I Spit on Your Grave}} * {{rotten-tomatoes|i_spit_on_your_grave_2010|I Spit on Your Grave}} {{I Spit on Your Grave}} {{DEFAULTSORT:I Spit On Your Grave}} [[Category:2010 films]] [[Category:2010 horror films]] [[Category:2010s crime thriller films]] [[Category:2010s horror thriller films]] [[Category:2010s independent films]] [[Category:2010s serial killer films]] [[Category:American crime thriller films]] [[Category:American exploitation films]] [[Category:American film remakes]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American horror thriller films]] [[Category:American independent films]] [[Category:American splatter films]] [[Category:CineTel Films films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Feminist films]] [[Category:Films about writers]] [[Category:Films directed by Steven R. {{distinguish|text=scientist [[Cathy Drennan]]}} '''Kathryn M. Drennan''' is an [[United States|American]] writer, having worked for [[Carl Sagan]] on the mini-series ''[[Cosmos: A Personal Voyage]]'' in the early 1980s<ref>{{cite web|url=http://movies.ign.com/articles/035/035904p1.html |title=Interview with J. Michael Straczynski (Part 1 of 4) |work=IGN |accessdate=5 October 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080820034004/http://movies.ign.com/articles/035/035904p1.html |archivedate=20 August 2008 |df= }}</ref> and for [[Michael Piller]], producer at the time for ''[[Star Trek: The Next Generation]]'', in the early 1990s.<ref>Nazzaro, Joe (2002). ''Writing Science Fiction and Fantasy Television''. Titan Books: {{ISBN|1-84023-383-4}}.</ref> She also contributed articles to several magazines, including ''[[Starlog]]''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000408/publicity|title=Jonathan Frakes - Publicity|work=IMDb|accessdate=5 October 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alienscollection.com/kmdrennan.html|title=The Howling Commando|publisher=Alienscollection.com|accessdate=5 October 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0649055/publicity|title=David Opatoshu - Publicity|work=IMDb|accessdate=5 October 2014}}</ref> and ''[[Twilight Zone Magazine]]''.<ref name="TwiZone">{{cite web|url=http://www.locusmag.com/index/s234.htm|title=Stories, Listed by Author|publisher=Locusmag.com|accessdate=5 October 2014}}</ref> She was married to [[J. Michael Straczynski]], creator of ''[[Babylon 5]]'', and wrote articles about [[Rod Serling]]'s ''[[Night Gallery]]'' for ''Twilight Zone Magazine'' together with him.<ref name="TwiZone"/> She wrote one script during ''Babylon 5'''s first season, "[[By Any Means Necessary (Babylon 5)|By Any Means Necessary]]" as well as the prose ''Babylon 5'' novel, ''[[To Dream in the City of Sorrows]]''. She also wrote scripts for two other shows Straczynski worked on, ''[[She-Ra: Princess of Power]]'' and ''[[The Real Ghostbusters]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0237472/|title=Kathryn M. Drennan|work=IMDb|accessdate=5 October 2014}}</ref>
== Personal life == She met [[J. Michael Straczynski]] while they were both at [[San Diego State University]]. They moved to [[Los Angeles]] on April 1, 1981. They married in 1983,<ref>[http://movies.ign.com/articles/035/035904p1.html] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080820034004/http://movies.ign.com/articles/035/035904p1.html |date=August 20, 2008 }}</ref> separated in 2002, and were divorced in 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/straczynski/status/409615521248583680|title=JMichael Straczynski on Twitter: "Before I get into any of this, I need to make one thing really clear, so there are no misunderstandings: I live... http://t.co/EIU4MEAxeB"|publisher=T.co|accessdate=5 October 2014}}</ref>
==Writings==
=== Novels === *''Babylon 5'' Book #9: ''[[To Dream in the City of Sorrows]]'' (covering the life of [[Jeffrey Sinclair]] from the end of season 1 until his final departure in season 3)
=== Articles and stories in magazines === *"The Mind Withdrawn", short story published in the [[Star Trek]] fanzine, ''Galactic Discourse'' #1, Feb 1977. *"Rod Serling's ''Night Gallery''" w/ J. Michael Straczynski, article in ''[[Twilight Zone Magazine]]'', 3 issues, Mar - Aug 1985. *"A Show by Show Guide to Rod Serling's ''Night Gallery''" w/ J. Michael Straczynski, article in ''Twilight Zone Magazine'', 11 issues, Mar 1985 - Jun 1989. *"David Opatoshu and A Taste of Armageddon", article in ''[[Starlog]]'', Jun 1987. *"Bill Paxton: The Howling Commando", article in ''Starlog'', Jan 1988. *"Wil Wheaton: Acting Ensign", article in ''Starlog'', Apr 1988. *"Jonathan Frakes: One on One", article in ''Starlog'', Jun 1988. *"The Art of ''Night Gallery'', article in ''Twilight Zone Magazine'', Feb 1989. *"DeForest Kelley's Medical Plan", article in ''Starlog'', Jun 1989. *"DeForest Kelley's Western Days", article in ''Starlog'', Jul 1989. *"A Test of Character", article in ''Starlog'', Dec 1989.
=== Television credits === *''[[She-Ra: Princess of Power]]'' **"The Unicorn King" *''[[The Real Ghostbusters]]'' **"Night Game" **"Egon's Dragon" **"The Man Who Never Reached Home" *''[[Babylon 5]]'' **"[[By Any Means Necessary (Babylon 5)|By Any Means Necessary]]"

{{refimprove|date=April 2015}} [[File:Highlands.jpg|thumb|300px|A "Keep Louisville Weird" billboard in East Louisville's [[The Highlands, Louisville|Highlands]] district, specifically, the [[Bonnycastle, Louisville|Bonnycastle]] neighborhood]] "'''Keep Louisville Weird'''" is a popular [[slogan]] adopted by the '''Louisville Independent Business Alliance''' ('''LIBA''')<ref name=birthday>{{cite web | url=http://www.courier-journal.com/story/news/local/2015/02/09/weird-birthday-bash-planned-alliance/23142063/ | title=Group to celebrate Keeping Louisville Weird | publisher=The Courier-Journal | date=16 February 2015 | accessdate=25 April 2015 | author=Sheldon S. Shafer}}</ref> that appears on bumper stickers as well as numerous signs and public buildings throughout [[Louisville, Kentucky]] and its surrounding metro area, especially in [[The Highlands, Louisville|The Highlands]] district. A variation of the slogan, "Keep Highland Weird", is also used in the Highlands district. It originated from the "[[Keep Austin Weird]]" slogan and is intended to promote [[Small business|local businesses]], though it has evolved into an all-encompassing slogan that secondarily promotes individuality, expressionism, local art, as well as atypical lifestyle choices and leisure activities. The slogan frequently inspires articles and debate that attempt to quantify the exact level to which Louisville is considered [[wikt:weird|weird]], unusual or eccentric.<ref>[https://www.usatoday.com/story/travel/destinations/2013/12/18/louisville-nulu-kentucky-shopping-restaurant-district/4063197/ "Heartland Hotspots: In 'New Louisville,' weird works"]. ''USA Today'', Chie Davis, ''USA TODAY'' December 18, 2013</ref>
The Louisville Independent Business Alliance is among at least 85 community organizations affiliated with the [[American Independent Business Alliance]], a national non-profit that supports and connects pro-local community-based organizations.
==History== The slogan was created by the Louisville Independent Business Alliance with the intention of supporting local businesses and small business owners. It was based on the [[Keep Austin Weird]] organization and slogan in [[Austin, Texas|Austin]], [[Texas]], and the [[Keep Portland Weird]] slogan used in [[Portland, Oregon|Portland]], [[Oregon]], and was brought to Louisville shortly after around 2005.<ref name=birthday />
==See also== * [[Keep Portland Weird]] * [[Keep Indy Indie]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * {{official website|http://www.keeplouisvilleweird.com/}}

[[File:Opernhaus Leipzig Langzeitbelichtung Tag.jpg|thumb|Frontage of Leipzig Opera building.]] [[File:Opernhaus Leipzig Abend Nacht.jpg|thumb|Frontage of Leipzig Opera building during night.]] [[File:Opernhaus Leipzig Zuschauerraum mit Loge.jpg|thumb|right|Interior of Leipzig Opera]] The '''Leipzig Opera''' (in German: '''{{Lang|de|Oper Leipzig}}''') is an [[opera house]] and [[opera]] company located at the [[Augustusplatz]] in [[Leipzig]], Germany.
==History== The Leipzig Opera traces its establishment to the year 1693, making it the third oldest opera venue in Europe after [[La Fenice]] (Venice, Italy) and the [[Hamburg State Opera]] (Hamburg, Germany). The director of many of those early operas at the original {{Lang|de|Opernhaus auf dem [[Brühl (Leipzig)|Brühl]]}} was [[Georg Philipp Telemann|Telemann]].
The Leipzig Opera does not have its own opera orchestra – the [[Leipzig Gewandhaus Orchestra]] performs as its orchestra. This relationship began in 1766 with performances of the [[Singspiel]] ''{{Lang|de|[[Die verwandelten Weiber|Die verwandelten Weiber, oder Der Teufel ist los]]}}'' by [[Johann Adam Hiller]].
==Opera House, 1868== [[File:Leipzig_um_1900.jpg|thumb|right|Neues Theater, circa 1900.]]
The previous theater (the "{{Lang|de|Neues Theater}}") was inaugurated on 28 January 1868 with ''Jubilee Overture'' by [[Carl Maria von Weber]] and the overture for ''[[Iphigénie en Aulide]]'' by [[Christoph Willibald Gluck|Gluck]] and [[Johann Wolfgang von Goethe|Goethe]]'s play ''[[Iphigenia in Tauris (Goethe)|Iphigenia in Tauris]]''. From 1886 to 1888, [[Gustav Mahler]] was the second conductor; [[Arthur Nikisch]] was his superior. During an [[Strategic bombing|air raid]] in the night of 3 December 1943, part of the [[bombing of Leipzig in World War II]], the theater was destroyed, as were all Leipzig's theatres.
==Opera House, 1960== Construction of the modern opera house began in 1956. The theater was inaugurated on 8 October 1960 with a performance of [[Richard Wagner|Wagner]]'s ''[[Die Meistersinger von Nürnberg]]''.<ref>[http://www.oper-leipzig-technik.de/pdf_dokumente/eroffnungsprogramm.pdf "{{Lang|de|Die ersten Vorstellungen in der Neuen Oper Leipzig}}"], [http://www.oper-leipzig-technik.de/ Oper Leipzig – Die Technik]</ref>
Since 2009, [[Ulf Schirmer]] is the ''[[Generalmusikdirektor]]'' (General Music Director, or GMD); he was elected artistic director in 2011 for a five-year term.
==General Music Directors (GMD)== {{div col|colwidth=15em|rules=yes}} * [[Arthur Nikisch]] (1878) * [[Gustav Mahler]] (1886–1888) * Otto Lohse (1912) * Gustav Brecher (1923) * Paul Schmitz (1932) * Helmut Seydelmann (1951) * Paul Schmitz (1964) * [[Lothar Zagrosek]] (1990–1992) * Jiri Kout (1993) * [[Michail Jurowski]] (1999) * [[Riccardo Chailly]] (2005–2008) * [[Ulf Schirmer]] (2009–present) {{div col end}}
==References== <references />
==External links== {{Commons category|Opernhaus Leipzig}} *[http://www.oper-leipzig.de Oper Leipzig's website] *[http://www.amadelio.com/amadelio_vlog/archiv/archiv_vlog_rel/vlog_2006_diaz.htm/ Interview with Damien Diaz, Principal Dancer under Uwe Scholz]

[[File:Leningrad Codex Carpet page e.jpg|thumb|Leningrad Codex (cover page E, folio 474a)]]
The '''Leningrad Codex''' (Latin: ''Codex Leningradensis'', the "[[codex]] of [[Leningrad]]") is the oldest ''complete'' manuscript of the [[Hebrew Bible]] in Hebrew, using the [[Masoretic Text]] and [[Tiberian vocalization]].<ref>There are older manuscripts of translations into other languages, such as the [[Codex Amiatinus]] in Latin.</ref> It is dated 1008 CE (or possibly 1009) according to its [[colophon (publishing)|colophon]].<ref>Foreword by Gérard E. Weil to ''[[Biblia Hebraica Stuttgartensia]]'', 1977.</ref> The [[Aleppo Codex]], against which the Leningrad Codex was corrected, is several decades older, but parts of it have been missing since 1947, making the Leningrad Codex the oldest complete codex of the Tiberian mesorah that has survived intact to this day.
In modern times, the Leningrad Codex is significant as the Hebrew text reproduced in ''[[Biblia Hebraica (Kittel)|Biblia Hebraica]]'' (1937) and ''[[Biblia Hebraica Stuttgartensia]]'' (1977). It also serves as a primary source for the recovery of details in the missing parts of the Aleppo Codex.
==Name== The Leningrad Codex (a codex is a handwritten book as opposed to a [[scroll]]) is so named because it has been housed at the [[National Library of Russia]] in [[Saint Petersburg]] since 1863. In 1924, after the [[Russian Revolution of 1917|Russian Revolution]], Petrograd (formerly Saint Petersburg) was renamed Leningrad, and, because the codex was used as the basic text for the Biblia Hebraica since 1937, it became internationally known as the "Leningrad Codex". Although in 1991, after the dissolution of the Soviet Union, the city's original name was restored to St Petersburg, the National Library of Russia requested that "Leningrad" be retained in the name of the codex. Nonetheless, the Codex is occasionally referred to as the Codex Petersburgensis or Petropolitanus, or the St. Petersburg Codex. This is ambiguous as, since 1876, these appellations refer to a different biblical codex (MS. Heb B 3) which is even older (916 CE), but contains only the later Prophets.
==Contents== The biblical text as found in the codex contains the Hebrew letter-text along with Tiberian [[niqqud|vowels]] and [[cantillation]] signs. In addition, there are [[masoretic notes]] in the margins. There are also various technical supplements dealing with textual and linguistic details, many of which are painted in geometrical forms. The codex is written on parchment and bound in leather.
The Leningrad Codex, in extraordinarily pristine condition after a millennium, also provides an example of medieval Jewish art. Sixteen of the pages contain decorative geometric patterns that illuminate passages from the text. The [[carpet page]] shows a star with the names of the scribes on the edges and a blessing written in the middle.
The order of the books in the Leningrad Codex follows the Tiberian textual tradition, which is also that of the later tradition of [[Sephardic]] biblical manuscripts. This order for the books differs markedly from that of most printed Hebrew bibles for the books of the [[Ketuvim]]. In the Leningrad Codex, the order of the Ketuvim is: Chronicles, Psalms, Job, Proverbs, Ruth, Song of Songs, Ecclesiastes, Lamentations, Esther, Daniel, Ezra-Nehemiah. The full order of the books is given below.
==History== [[File:LeningradCodex text.jpg|thumb|Leningrad Codex text sample, portions of Exodus 15:21-16:3]]
According to its [[colophon (publishing)|colophon]], the [[codex]] was copied in [[Cairo]]<ref>{{cite web|last1=Stuhlman|first1=Daniel D.|title=The Leningrad Codex|url=http://home.earthlink.net/~ddstuhlman/crc10.htm|publisher=Librarian's Lobby|accessdate=13 October 2014|date=1 March 1998}}</ref> from manuscripts written by [[Aaron ben Moses ben Asher]]. It has been claimed to be a product of the Asher scriptorium itself; however, there is no evidence that Asher ever saw it. Unusual for a masoretic codex, the same man (Samuel ben Jacob) wrote the consonants, the vowels and the Masoretic notes. In its vocalization system (vowel points and [[cantillation]]) it is considered by scholars to be the most faithful representative of ben Asher's tradition apart from the Aleppo Codex (edited by ben Asher himself). Its letter-text is not superb, however, and contradicts its own masoretic apparatus in many hundreds of places.<ref>On the vocalization and letter-text of the Leningrad Codex see Israel Yeivin, ''The Aleppo Codex of the Bible: A Study of its Vocalization and Accentuation (Jerusalem: Magnes, 1968) pp. 357-359 (Hebrew).</ref> There are numerous alterations and erasures, and it was suggested by [[Moshe Goshen-Gottstein]] that an existing text not following Asher's rules was heavily amended so as to make it conform to these rules.
The codex is now preserved in the [[National Library of Russia]], accessioned as "Firkovich B 19 A". Its former owner, the [[Crimean Karaite]] collector [[Abraham Firkovich]], left no indication in his writings where he had acquired the codex, which was taken to Odessa in 1838 and later transferred to the Imperial Library in St Petersburg.
==Modern editions== ===Biblia Hebraica=== In 1935, the Leningrad Codex was lent to the Old Testament Seminar of the University of Leipzig for two years while [[Paul E. Kahle]] supervised its transcription for the Hebrew text of the third edition of ''[[Biblia Hebraica (Kittel)|Biblia Hebraica]]'' (BHK), published in Stuttgart, 1937. The codex was also used for ''[[Biblia Hebraica Stuttgartensia]]'' (BHS) in 1977, and is being used for [[Biblia Hebraica Quinta]] (BHQ).
As an original work by Tiberian masoretes, the Leningrad Codex was older by several centuries than the other Hebrew manuscripts which had been used for all previous editions of printed Hebrew bibles until [[Biblia Hebraica (disambiguation)|Biblia Hebraica]].
The Westminster Leningrad Codex is an online digital version of the Leningrad Codex maintained by the J. Alan Groves Center for Advanced Biblical Research at the [[Westminster Theological Seminary]]. This is a verified version of the Michigan-Claremont text, transcribed from BHS at the [[University of Michigan]] in 1981-1982 under the direction of H. Van Dyke Parunak (of the University of Michigan) and Richard E. Whitaker (of the Institute for Antiquity and Christianity, Claremont Graduate University) with funding from the Packard Foundation and the University of Michigan,<ref>Introductory notes to the Bibleworks WTT text, www.bibleworks.com</ref> with further proofreading and corrections. The online version includes transcription notes and tools for analyzing syntax.
===Jewish editions=== The Leningrad Codex also served as the basis for two important modern Jewish editions of the Hebrew Bible ([[Tanakh]]): *The [[Aron Dotan|Dotan]] edition, which was distributed to soldiers in mass quantities as the official [[Tanakh]] of the [[Israel Defense Forces]] throughout the 1990s. *The [[New Jewish Publication Society of America Version|''JPS Hebrew-English Tanakh'']] (Philadelphia, 1999) and the various volumes of the JPS Torah Commentary and JPS Bible Commentary.
For minute masoretic details, however, Israeli and Jewish scholars have shown a marked preference for modern Hebrew editions based upon the Aleppo Codex. These editions use the Leningrad Codex as the most important source (but not the only one) for the reconstruction of parts of the Aleppo Codex that have been missing since 1947.

{{more citations needed|date=August 2018}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Lil Miquela | image = Miquela Family Tree cropped.png | image_size = | landscape = | alt = | caption = | background = solo_singer | alias = {{hlist|Miquela Sousa|Miquela}} | origin = [[Los Angeles]], [[California]], [[United States]] | genre = {{hlist|[[Contemporary R&B|R&B]]|[[electronic music|electronic]]|[[pop music|pop]]}} | occupation = {{hlist|Instagram personality|singer|model}} | instrument = vocals | years_active = 2016–present | label = | associated_acts = {{hlist|[[Anamanaguchi]]|[[Baauer]]}} | website = [https://www.instagram.com/lilmiquela/?hl=en Instagram profile] }}
'''Miquela Sousa''', better known as '''Lil Miquela''', is a fictional character created by [[Yung Skeeter|Trevor McFedries]] and Sara Decou as a digital art project.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.instagram.com/brud.fyi/|title=Brud (@brud.fyi) • Instagram photos and videos|website=www.instagram.com|language=en|access-date=2018-05-21}}</ref><ref name="Billboard">{{Cite news|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/international/7964899/virtual-instagram-miquela-controversy-interview|title=Virtual It-Singer Miquela Says 'Controversy Doesn't Mean Anything': Interview|work=Billboard|access-date=2017-12-17}}</ref><ref name="Highsnobiety">{{cite web|last1=Gorsler|first1=Fabian|title=Meet Lil Miquela: Fashion’s First Virtual Instagram Influencer|url=https://www.highsnobiety.com/p/lil-miquela-virtual-influencer-instagram/?format=amp|website=Highsnobiety|accessdate=1 April 2018|language=en}}</ref><ref name="HYPEBEAST">{{cite web|last1=Rouse|first1=Isaac|title=Miquela Sousa Is Fashion's First Computer Generated Influencer|url=https://hypebeast.com/2018/2/miquela-sousa-first-computer-generated-fashion-influencer?amp=1|website=HYPEBEAST|accessdate=1 April 2018|language=en|date=5 February 2018}}</ref><ref name="FN">{{cite web|last1=McDonald|first1=Samantha|title=This Instagram Influencer Is Not Even Human|url=http://footwearnews.com/2018/influencers/technology/miquela-sousa-instagram-virtual-influencer-491637/amp/|website=FN|accessdate=1 April 2018|language=en|date=6 February 2018}}</ref> Miquela is an [[Instagram]] model and music artist claiming to be from [[Downey, California]].
The project began in 2016 as an [[Instagram]] profile. By April 2018, the account had amassed more than a million followers by portraying the lifestyle of an Instagram it-girl over social media.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/entry/lilmiquela-instagram_uk_57c94056e4b085cf1ecdc0af|title=Instagram's Latest 'It' Model Is Confusing The Hell Out Of Everyone|date=2016-09-02|newspaper=The Huffington Post|access-date=2017-02-23}}</ref> The account also details a fictional narrative which presents Miquela as a sentient robot in conflict with other digital projects created by McFedries and Decou.
In August 2017, Miquela released her first single, "Not Mine".<ref name="billboard.com">{{Cite news|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/pop/7898117/miquela-virtual-singer-instagram-not-mine-song-stream|title=Virtual Singer & Internet Star Miquela Shares Debut Single 'Not Mine'|work=Billboard|access-date=2017-11-05}}</ref> Her pivot into a music has been compared to virtual musicians [[Gorillaz]] and [[Hatsune Miku]].<ref name="Billboard"/>
==Origins== Miquela’s first Instagram post was made on April 22, 2016. The project garnered both intrigue and criticism for the character's digital appearance with fans and online commenters oscillating between positing that Miquela is an art project or a social experiment carried out by a real unidentified woman. Miquela was rumored to be a marketing gimmick for ''[[The Sims]]''.{{Citation needed|date=August 2018}} British model Emily Bador was rumored to be Miquela, fans citing the character's abundance of freckles. Bador openly acknowledged the physical similarity.{{Citation needed|date=August 2018}}
==Online presence== Miquela has been pictured with a number of celebrities including [[Diplo]], [[How to Dress Well]], killerandasweetthang founder Eileen Kelly, [[Molly Soda]], [[Nile Rogers]], and [[Samantha Urbani]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.instagram.com/lilmiquela/|title=*~ MIQUELA ~* (@lilmiquela) • Instagram photos and videos|website=www.instagram.com|language=en|access-date=2018-04-24}}</ref> She has been interviewed and or profiled in a number of publications including Refinery29, Vogue, Buzzfeed, v-files, Nylon, the Guardian, Business of Fashion, The Cut, and BBC.com.{{Citation needed|date=August 2018}} As well as by Shane Dawson, YouTube celebrity, in a [https://youtube.com/watch?v=NdNYAiU-SLI phone interview]<ref>{{Citation|last=shane|title=CONSPIRACY THEORIES & INTERVIEW WITH LIL MIQUELA|date=2017-09-18|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NdNYAiU-SLI|access-date=2018-10-24}}</ref>. She appeared on the cover of High Snobiety in April 2018.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.highsnobiety.com/p/lil-miquela-cover-story-issue-16/|title=Meet Lil Miquela, the AI Influencer on the Cover of Our New Print Issue|website=High Snobiety|language=en|access-date=2018-08-17}}</ref> In February 2018, Miquela did an Instagram takeover for Prada as part of Milan Fashion Week.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.vogue.com/article/prada-instagram-gifs-lil-miquela|title=Prada Launches Instagram GIFs With Help From a Fictional It Girl|work=Vogue|access-date=2018-04-24|language=en}}</ref>
===Online narratives=== In April 2018, a trans-media story began to play out on Miquela's Instagram involving [https://www.instagram.com/blawko22 @Blawko22], and [https://www.instagram.com/bermudaisbae/ @BermudaIsBae], two other virtual Instagram accounts who are presented as "sentient robots." The story suggests that two organizations are responsible for the creation of these sentient robots. In the narrative, fictional brand Brud created Miquela and "Blawko22" while competing fictional brand Cain Intelligence created "BermudaIsBae".
On April 17, all of Miquela's Instagram posts were removed. "BermudaIsBae" was purported to have hacked Miquela's account. The two online personas then began posting pictures together as Miquela worked to reclaim the original account.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.instagram.com/p/BhuruzXHetm/?taken-by=bermudaisbae|title=Bermuda on Instagram: "More emotional than I thought it would be. Despite it all, there’s only three of us out there and we need to stick together. We talked it…"|website=Instagram|language=en|access-date=2018-04-24}}</ref> After reclaiming the account, Miquela posted a series of notes saying that she is a robot and claiming sentience.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.instagram.com/p/BkjEPEuFdp0/?taken-by=lilmiquela|title=Lil Miquela on Instagram: "So I pull up to the trail and there she is. No rattlesnakes. No hiking. Just a robot sitting on the curb in skinny jeans and wedges. She said it’s the only way she could get my attention since I haven’t answered her texts since we went to the mall a couple weeks back. She just wanted to hang out. So here we are 'hanging out.'"|website=Instagram|language=en|access-date=2018-08-17}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.instagram.com/p/BjvhTbylRcD/?taken-by=lilmiquela|title=Lil Miquela on Instagram: "So, Brud programmed my memories, claiming I’m from a place called Downey. It’s right in-between Los Angeles and Disneyland. Even though that sounds like a dream to me, I had to come check it out for myself..."|website=Instagram|accessdate=2018-08-17}}</ref>
==Music career== Miquela has released several singles since her debut with "Not Mine," including "You Should be Alone," "Over You," and a collaboration with [[Baauer]] titled "Hate Me." Her musical style is characterized by the use of [[auto-tune]] and [[trap music|trap]]-influenced production. Her music has been released on [[YouTube]] and [[Spotify]]. Miquela's sound is purportedly based off of the soundtrack to Sam Raimi's 1981 cult classic, [[Evil Dead]].

{{Comics navbar|title=List of comics awards}} This is a '''list of comics awards''' from around the world. This list includes awards given out for achievements in [[cartooning]], [[comic books]], [[comic strips]] and [[graphic novels]]. {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2010}} List of works by the German architect [[Erich Mendelsohn]]. [[Image:Bet Tahara - Olsztyn.jpg|thumb|Outside view of the Taharah Building in Allenstein (Olsztyn)]] [[Image:Luckenwalde HatFactory inner view.jpg|thumb|Inner view of the Hat Factory in Luckenwalde]] [[Image:Mosseverlagshausberlin.jpg|thumb|[[Mossehaus]] in Berlin]] [[Image:Einsteintower back.jpg|thumb|Rear view of the [[Einstein Tower]] in [[Potsdam]]]] [[Image:Hadassah University Hospital, Mt. Scopus, Jerusalem.jpg|thumb|Hadassah University Hospital, Mt. Scopus, [[Jerusalem]]]] [[Image:Wroclaw Mendelsohn Petersdorff.jpg|thumb|Petersdorff Shopping Centre in [[Wrocław|Breslau]], now [[Wrocław]] (Detail)]] <!-- Image with inadequate rationale removed: [[Image:cohenhouse.jpg|thumb|[[Cohen House, London|Cohen House]] in London]] -->
*[[Bereavement in Judaism#Preparing the body — Taharah|Taharah]] building in [[Allenstein]] (1913), today known as the [[Mendelsohn house]]. *Workers' colony for the Builders' Union in [[Luckenwalde]] (1919–1920) *Garden pavilion of the Herrmann family, Luckenwalde (1920) *Work hall of the Herrmann hat factory, Luckenwalde (1919–1920) *Conversion of the administration building of the ''Hausleben'' insurance company, Berlin (1920) *[[Einsteinturm]] (Observatory on the [[Telegraphenberg]]) in [[Potsdam]], 1917 or 1920–1921 ''(building), 1921–1924 (technical equipment).'' The building, its expressionistic form giving the impression of [[concrete]] as a building material, was mostly built in brick and then covered with plaster. Mendelsohn explained this was because of delivery problems; however, it is presumed that the real reason for the choice of building materials was problems with constructing the casing. *Double villa on Karolingerplatz, Berlin (1921–1922) *Steinberg hat factory, Herrmann & Co, Luckenwalde (1921–1923) with a strict, angular form *[[Mossehaus]], conversion of the offices and press of Rudolf Mosse, Berlin (1921–1923) *Weichmann silk factory, [[Gleiwitz]], [[Schlesien]] (1922) *Villa of Dr. Sternefeld, Berlin, (1923–1924) *Furs factory of C. A. Herpich and Sons, Berlin (1924–1929) *Schocken department store, [[Nuremberg]] (1925–1926) *[[Red Flag Textile Factory]], [[Leningrad]], (1926) *Extension and conversion of Cohen & Epstein department store, [[Duisburg]] (1925–1927) *Cottage of Dr. Bejach, [[Berlin-Steinstücken]] (1926–1927) *[[Schocken Department Store Stuttgart|Schocken department store]], [[Stuttgart]] (1926–1928). The department store, together with the [[Tagblatt-Turm]] (1924–1928) of [[Ernst-Otto Oßwald]] across the way, constituted an impressive ensemble of modern architecture, and was damaged only lightly in World War II. In 1960, the city Stuttgart demolished both, despite international protest. In its place today stands [[Egon Eiermann]]'s unremarkable department store building (Galeria Kaufhof, previously Horten). *Exhibition pavilion for the publishing house Rudolf Mosse at the "[[Pressa]]" in [[Cologne]] (1928) *Rudolf Petersdorff store, [[Breslau]] (1927–1928) *Woga-Komplex and [[Schaubühne|Universum-Kino]] (cinema), Berlin (1925–1931) *Jüdischer Friedhof (Jewish cemetery), [[Königsberg]], [[East Prussia]] (1927–1929) *Schocken department store, [[Chemnitz]] 1927–1930, known for its arched front with horizontal strips of windows. *His own home, Am Rupenhorn, Berlin (1928–1930) *House of the German Metal Workers' Union, [[Berlin-Kreuzberg]] (1928–1930) *[[Columbushaus|Columbus-Haus]], [[Potsdamer Platz]], Berlin (1928–1932), originally a store for ''Galeries Lafayette'', not to be confused with the "[[Columbia-Haus]]" in [[Berlin-Tempelhof]], which was torn down in 1938 *Jewish youth center, [[Essen]] (1930–1933) *Doblouggården store, [[Oslo]], Norway (1932). Built by Rudolf Emil Jacobsen from Mendelsohn's plans *[[The De La Warr Pavilion]], [[Bexhill-on-Sea]], [[Sussex]], England (1934). In collaboration with [[Serge Chermayeff]]. *Nimmo House (later renamed [[Shrubs Wood]] by former owner [[Bridget D'Oyly Carte]]), [[Chalfont St Giles]], [[Buckinghamshire]], England (1933–1934). In collaboration with [[Serge Chermayeff]]. *[[Cohen House, London|Cohen House]], [[Chelsea, London]] (1934–1936). In collaboration with [[Serge Chermayeff]]. *Gilbey Firm, [[Camden Town|Camden]], London (1935–1936). In collaboration with [[Serge Chermayeff]]. *[[Weizmann House]], [[Weizmann Institute]] campus, [[Rehovot]] near [[Tel Aviv]] (1935–1936) *Built around the same time: a cluster of three buildings on the [[Weizmann Institute]] campus, presently housing high-resolution [[NMR spectroscopy|NMR]], biological [[MRI]], and the Kimmel Center for Archeology, respectively *Zalman [[Salman Schocken|Schocken]] villa and library, [[Jerusalem]] (1934–1936) *[[Hebrew University]], Jerusalem (1934–1940) *[[Hadassah Medical Center|Hadassah University Hospital, Mt. Scopus]], Jerusalem (1934–1939) *[[Bank Leumi|Anglo-Palestine-Bank]], [[Jaffa Road]] Jerusalem (1936–1939) *[[Rambam Hospital|Haifa Municipal Hospital]], [[Haifa]] (1937–1938) *Synagogue B'Nai Amoona, now Center of Creative Arts, [[University City, Missouri]] (1946–1950) *Maimonides Hospital, San Francisco (1946–1950) *[[Park Synagogue]], [[Cleveland Heights, Ohio|Cleveland Heights]], Ohio (1946–1953) *Russell house, San Francisco (1947–1951) *Emanu-El Synagogue, [[Grand Rapids, Michigan]], (1948–1954) *[[Mount Zion Temple |Mount Zion Synagogue]], [[St. Paul, Minnesota]] (1950–1954)
